G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Court “may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parties” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, because this Court issued the existing custody judgment and the child resides within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 76, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20132.proposition: Because Emily is now of school age and subject to compulsory attendance laws under G.L. c. 76, §§ 1–2, the Defendant’s recurring failure to ensure her attendance on Mondays and at tutoring sessions has more serious legal and practical consequences than any attendance issues that may have existed when she was younger.

G.L. c. 76, \u00a7 1.proposition: The child’s educational stability and regular school attendance are central components of her best interests and are explicitly protected by Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 76, § 1 (compulsory school attendance); G.L. c. 119, § 51A (educational neglect as a potential form of neglect).

G.L. c. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: The child’s educational stability and regular school attendance are central components of her best interests and are explicitly protected by Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 76, § 1 (compulsory school attendance); G.L. c. 119, § 51A (educational neglect as a potential form of neglect).

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that a modification of custody or related orders requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an initial custody judgment and addresses how courts must consider domestic violence and make explicit findings regarding its impact and statutory requirements for shared custody. It does not discuss the familiar two‑part standard for modification of custody (material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests of the child), nor is it a modification case. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts appellate courts emphasize that the best interests of the child encompass the child’s physical, emotional, and educational welfare. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843–44 (court must consider “emotional, intellectual, moral and physical needs” of child).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and explains that the judge must consider a broad range of factors related to the child’s welfare. It emphasizes evaluation of the child’s physical needs, medical care, educational issues, and overall welfare, which together encompass physical, emotional, and educational well-being. Thus, the case is properly cited for the proposition that best interests analysis includes emotional, intellectual, moral, and physical needs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child… [including] that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues, and is the one who ‘preoccupies herself’ with Kali’s care regarding clothing, hygiene, doctor’s appointments, and child care providers… that the mother is more ‘attuned’ to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs and is better able to provide for Kali’s welfare and physical needs during the week….”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that a modification of custody or related orders requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: This opinion is about an initial custody determination in a paternity action under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification of an existing final custody judgment. The court repeatedly frames the issue as a best‑interests analysis and discusses the statutory factors, but it does not articulate or apply the two‑part standard of (1) material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment and (2) necessity of modification in the child’s best interests. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .” R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.

Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that a modification of custody or related orders requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes that a custody modification must be based on a change in circumstances, citing Hinds v. Hinds and stating there was a “relevant change of circumstances adequate to support a change in the order for custody.” It also emphasizes that the welfare of the child is the controlling consideration in deciding custody. However, the two-part standard is not articulated in a single, formulaic sentence; it is inferred from the combination of the change-in-circumstances language and the best‑interests/welfare discussion, so support is somewhat implicit rather than explicitly framed as a test.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).relevant_excerpt: “Manifestly there was a relevant change of circumstances (Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191) adequate to support a change in the order for custody. There was strong assurance of the mother’s ability to offer a good home and the daughter was no longer in a settled home.… It is well settled that the welfare of the child is the controlling consideration and custody is not to be awarded or changed to discipline either party.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that a modification of custody or related orders requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes G.L. c. 208, § 28 and explains that a Probate Court may modify an earlier custody judgment only upon finding both (1) a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and (2) that the modification “is necessary in the best interests of the children.” The court then applies this two-part standard to the mother’s complaint for modification. This aligns with and supports the proposition about the longstanding Massachusetts standard for modification of custody orders.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ See Hartog v. Hartog, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 124, 128 (1989), and cases cited.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Joint legal custody presupposes the parents’ “ability and willingness to cooperate in making major decisions for the child,” including decisions regarding education and schooling. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981) (joint custody appropriate only where parents can cooperate and communicate effectively about the child’s welfare).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses when joint custody is appropriate and expressly conditions it on the parents’ ability and willingness to cooperate and make major child‑rearing decisions together. The court emphasizes that joint custody means joint decision‑making, cites disagreement over major areas including education and schooling, and concludes that joint custody is suitable primarily for relatively amicable parents who can work together on such decisions. This aligns with the proposition that joint legal custody presupposes cooperative decision‑making on major issues, including education.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’… Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests… [I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents… together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’ … [T]he parties… disagree with respect to child rearing both in the major areas such as schooling, medical treatment, religion, education….”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.proposition: Where parents are unable to cooperate on important issues or where one parent consistently acts in a way that undermines the child’s welfare, it is appropriate for the Court to modify the existing orders and allocate decision‑making authority to one parent. See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547–49 (2010) (court may modify custody if joint custody no longer serves child’s best interests); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183–86 (2006) (modification to address changed circumstances impacting child’s best interests).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a relocating sole legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not address modification of joint custody orders, parental inability to cooperate, or reallocating decision‑making authority between two legal parents. The opinion is cited there only for the proposition that a court may not disturb a fit mother’s relocation when she was the sole legal parent at the time, not for modifying joint custody based on parental conflict or undermining a child’s welfare.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’… After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart…and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a).”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: Where parents are unable to cooperate on important issues or where one parent consistently acts in a way that undermines the child’s welfare, it is appropriate for the Court to modify the existing orders and allocate decision‑making authority to one parent. See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547–49 (2010) (court may modify custody if joint custody no longer serves child’s best interests); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183–86 (2006) (modification to address changed circumstances impacting child’s best interests).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman addresses the standard for removal/relocation under G.L. c. 208, § 30 when parents share joint legal and physical custody, focusing on a best‑interests analysis in that context. The court does not discuss modifying existing custody orders to reallocate decision‑making authority to one parent due to inability to cooperate or undermining the child’s welfare; in fact, the judge declined to award sole physical custody to either party and left joint custody in place. Thus, Mason supports use of a best‑interests standard upon changed circumstances in relocation cases, but not the specific proposition about modifying orders to allocate decision‑making to one parent.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court… and the judge did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

App. Ct. 1114 (20.proposition: In deciding whether to grant a complaint for modification, the Court may consider the pattern of a parent’s conduct and its effect on the child’s educational prospects and overall well‑being, rather than waiting for irreparable harm.
